captions.text:
The President:
Hi everybody.

Ever since the
internet was created,

it's been organized
around basic principles

of openness, fairness,
and freedom.

There are no gatekeepers
deciding which sites
you get to access.

There are no toll roads on
the information superhighway.

This set of principles,
the idea of net neutrality,

has unleashed the
power of the internet,

and given innovators
the chance to thrive.

Abandoning these
principles would threaten

to end the internet
as we know it.

That's why I'm
laying out a plan

to keep the internet
free and open.

And that's why
I'm urging

the Federal
Communications Commission

to do everything
they can to protect

net neutrality
for everyone.

They should make it clear that
whether you use a computer,

phone or tablet, internet
providers have a legal

obligation not to block or
limit your access to a website.

Cable companies can't
decide which online stores

you can shop at, or
which streaming services
you can use.

And they can't let any
company pay for priority
over its competitors.

To put these
protections in place,

I'm asking the FCC to reclassify
internet service under

Title II of a law known as
the Telecommunications Act.

In plain English, I'm asking
them to recognize that for most

Americans, the internet has
become an essential part

of everyday communication
and everyday life.

The FCC is an
independent agency,

and ultimately this
decision is theirs alone.

But the public has
already commented nearly

four million times, asking
the FCC to make sure

that consumers, not the cable
company, gets to decide
which sites they use.

Americans are making
their voices heard,

and standing up for the
principles that make

the internet a powerful
force for change.

As long as I'm
president, that's what
I'll be fighting for, too.

title: President Obama's Statement on Keeping the Internet Open and Free

comments.text:
Can +Narendra Modi take a leaf from +Barack Obama in clearly articulating 
their stand on #NetNeutrality?

Millions of netizens in India would want to know whether +BJP4India is 
hand-in-glove with greedy corporates who have funded their election, or 
with the millions of youth who actually voted them to power?

By deliberately choosing to be silent, sending out confused voices to the 
media and preaching that no #NetNeutrality  regulation would be needed, +
BJP4India has again demonstrated that they only have allegiance to 
corporate greed of the likes of +airtel India and #reliance  and other 
ISPs, and cares little about the voices of millions of Indians who have 
petitioned #TRAI .

The consultation paper of #TRAI  was not surprisingly loaded in favor of 
ISPs as it only represents the powerful telecom lobby. The open threat from 
the cartel of ISPs to increase the prices of broadband by 6X for internet 
as it stands today, unless we choose their specially crafted internet slice 
(featuring only companies who pay them to be on their prioritized service) 
should have been a clear eye-opener for the government to step in and issue 
policy directives, But, by not choosing to do so, and just paying 
lip-service to millions of Indians, +BJP4India is just again proving that 
#AccheDin  was just an election Jumla.

#SaveTheInternet﻿

comments.author: mamamia13

comments.text:
Let me make this real simple for you haters who keep spouting off about the 
free market:

Net neutrality is only an issue in the US because WE CURRENTLY DON'T HAVE A 
FREE MARKET WITH RESPECT TO INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDERS.

Thanks to local governments and a variety of other factors we have 
numerous, local monopolies that make controlling what a person gets and how 
much they pay for it disgustingly easy.  This is why ISPs like Comcast want 
to get rid of the current system where all data is treated equally. Comcast 
and their ilk know that if they do stuff people will hate, like charge you 
to go to Facebook, you will just have to suck up and pay it because THERE 
IS NO FREE MARKET IN OPERATION RIGHT NOW.

ISPs in other countries did not put up a fight over net neutrality laws 
that have already been passed, because they knew that if they screwed 
customers on data delivery with gated websites and additional fees people 
would just drop them and go to a better provider.  Unfortunately, I and 
millions of other Americans lack that choice.

LET ME REPEAT - DEFEATING NET NEUTRALITY IS ONLY IMPORTANT TO COMCAST, TIME 
WARNER, ETC. BECAUSE THE CURRENT SYSTEM LACKS THE SAFEGUARDS OF A FREE 
MARKET (informed customer, meaningful choices).﻿

comments.text:
"If you like your plan you can keep it"  Obama and his party want to make 
the internet a utility so THEY can REGULATE it and control everything you 
see.  Right now they have the major media in their pocket and the only 
media they can't control is the internet.  They also would LOVE to tax it 
and justify spending more money they don't have.﻿

comments.author: alfonso Gonzalez

comments.text:
How exactly, without new laws, COULD net neutrality go away?  The only one 
with the power to destroy net neutrality is the government itself.  If 
Disney doesn't let you on their premium site or Comcast slows you down...go 
with another company.  What's stopping you (besides other 
government regulations that make Comcast your 'sole source' and already 
prohibit competition)?

So many here don't see that what Obama is pushing has nothing at all to do 
with net neutrality...he's simply forcing businesses to supply cheap access 
to higher speeds and more content.  Thanks, Santa, but services cost money, 
and when you start to dry up the income, the goods and services suffer 
dearly.  His plan is redistribution, and it ends up hurting everyone 
involved except the government, who gets another rubber stamp to take more 
and more money out of the system, while the service providers are forced to 
cut corners trying to provide 'gold' service, to everyone, at 'bronze' 
prices.  The model isn't sustainable, and the internet turns into another 
VA or Obamacare system.﻿
comments.author: Advanced_Settings

comments.text:
It's the content of the message that is important.  The government action 
is another story but since this is a democracy the people should take 
action.  It should not be corporate driven.  They rely on the ignorance of 
the public.  How many even know the government themselves have been 
overlooking the internet from the start.  The first step as a citizen is 
educate yourself before making a comment.﻿
